title: O'Connell, judge spar over traffic school
text:
After a fiery confrontation with County Attorney Mike O'Connell, Jefferson District Judge Sean Delahanty promised to rule within a week about the fate of 2,300 motorists whose cases he has held hostage because of his concerns about Drive Safe Louisville, which has generated $1.3 million for O’Connell’s office.
Delahanty, miffed that O’Connell didn’t consult with judges before starting the program two years ago, grilled him about every aspect of it, suggesting it was too easy because nobody can fail and that it is unethical for prosecutors to use police to solicit business for it.
But O’Connell noted that the Kentucky General Assembly and Supreme Court have OK'd the programs, which are now operated by more than 80 county attorneys, and that Delahanty has no power to challenge it now.
“There is nothing further to do than dismiss these cases,” O’Connell asserted before angrily throwing his legal pad on the counsel table, which reverberated through the courtroom with a loud smack.
“If you can’t control yourself, perhaps calmer heads should take over,” Delahanty scolded him, suggesting that he let one of his assistants take over.
O’Connell continued, telling the court that 17,000 defendants have completed the two-hour online program and that it is unfair to keep 2,300 of them hanging. He noted 96 percent of them had tickets for the minor offenses of speeding or disregarding stop signs or traffic lights.
But Delahanty forced O’Connell to address a litany of questions about the ethics, finances and legality of the program, which O’Connell insisted already had been addressed.
Noting that prospective participants are promised their cases will be dismissed if they complete the program, Delahanty said, “You are holding yourself out as if there is no need for a judge in the process.”
“That is false and you know it’s false,” O’Connell shot back.
He said some motorists have lost job opportunities because their cases have been pending so long, while others don’t know their charges haven’t been dismissed.
Delahanty said he would view the Drive Safe Louisville video before deciding whether to dismiss the pending cases, which he said have come from several courts where judges also have concerns about the program.
He said none of the defendants “should lose any sleep” over their pending citations. “I am not going to punish them,” he said.
